paper_metadata.title: Subsoil‑potassium depletion accounts for the nutrient budget in high‑potassium agricultural soils
paper_metadata.research_focus: To evaluate the sensitivity of soil-K to K budgets, quantify soil-K changes over time along the soil profile, and identify soil variables that regulate soil-K depletion in high-potassium agricultural soils.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The entire study is centered on soil potassium, investigating its depletion, distribution across soil profiles, different chemical pools (exchangeable and slowly-exchangeable K), and the impact of agricultural practices and soil properties on its dynamics and availability.

research_context.study_objectives: To evaluate the sensitivity of soil-K to K budgets, quantify soil-K changes over time along the soil profile, and identify soil variables that regulate soil-K depletion. Hypotheses tested: (1) topsoil NH4-OAc-K is not sensitive to identify short-medium term K depletion trends in high native K soils; (2) vertical distribution patterns of both NH4-OAc-K and NaBPh4-K are affected by agricultural footprint, with significant depletion beyond topsoil (0–20 cm); and (3) soil K deviates from pristine conditions depending on soil factors related to K buffer capacity (soil texture, indigenous K richness).
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil potassium is the primary subject of investigation, with a focus on its various pools, vertical distribution, depletion rates, and the factors influencing its availability and cycling under agricultural management.
research_context.environmental_conditions: Temperate climate. Rainfall pattern is humid to the East and semi-arid to the West.
research_context.agricultural_context: Main crops are maize, soybean, and wheat. Historically, K fertilizer applications have been negligible due to high native soil K. Continuous K removal via harvest is gradually depleting soil K. Cropping systems included maize–wheat/double-cropped soybean (M-W/DS) and maize-full-season soybean-double-cropped wheat/soybean (M-FS-W/DS). No-tillage systems are mentioned as enhancing K stratification.
research_context.study_design: Four on-farm trials. Treatments included Control (no fertilizer), NPS (N, P, S fertilizers), and Pristine (adjacent uncultivated soil).
research_context.temporal_scope: Nine years (2000 to 2009). Soil samples were collected in early spring in 2000, 2004 (0–20 cm), and 2009 (0–100 cm).
research_context.spatial_scope: Four experimental sites (Balducchi, San Alfredo, La Blanca, La Hansa) differing in soil properties and management history. Soil profiles were sampled at five depths: 0–20, 20–40, 40–60, 60–80, and 80–100 cm.

pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Site-specific evolution in topsoil (0-20 cm) from 2000 to 2009; significant reductions in Balducchi and La Hansa, no differences in San Alfredo and La Blanca.

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Soil samples collected in early spring in 2000, 2004 (0–20 cm), and 2009 (0–100 cm).

long_term_trends.trend_description: Significant reductions observed in sites with longest agricultural history (Balducchi and La Hansa) from 2000 to 2009. No differences observed in sites with shorter farming history (San Alfredo and La Blanca).
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Significant reductions (p < 0.05) for Balducchi and La Hansa.

long_term_trends.trend_description: Progressive depletion due to prolonged and intensive agricultural use without K replenishment.
long_term_trends.time_period: Over the agricultural era (started ~100 years ago) and specifically during the 9-year study period.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Implied by negative K budgets and observed K depletion.

within_site_variability.variability_description: Significant differences between sites and treatments. Balducchi and San Alfredo showed most contrasting pristine NH4-OAc-K patterns. Significant interactions between treatment and soil depth were documented at all locations for NH4-OAc-K, and at Balducchi and La Blanca for NaBPh4-K.
within_site_variability.spatial_pattern: Depletion of both fractions was more pronounced at subsoil (20–100 cm) (55–83% for NH4-OAc-K and 74–95% for NaBPh4-K). In Balducchi and La Blanca (Hapludolls), higher NH4-OAc-K depletion rates (averaging 63% and 37%) were exacerbated towards the subsoil (60–100 cm). Contrastingly, in San Alfredo and La Hansa (Argiudolls), lower NH4-OAc-K reductions (averaging 25% and 27%) occurred mainly towards the topsoil.

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Rather equivalent across the four sites.
Balducchi showed larger impact, other sites varied in a small range.

scaling_considerations.scale_transition: From plot-level measurements to regional implications for Pampean Mollisols.
scaling_considerations.scaling_approach: Results are consistent with K recommendation systems based on combined topsoil and subsoil information.
scaling_considerations.uncertainty: Acknowledged need for more comprehensive studies on soil-K depletion trends in response to different crop management practices for Pampean Mollisols.

cycling_processes.description: Continuous removal of K from the soil via harvested crop products.
controlling_factors: Crop species (soybean exports more K than wheat/maize)
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Estimated from grain yield and grain K concentrations.

cycling_processes.description: K is released from less available pools (non-exchangeable K, K-bearing primary minerals) to more available pools (exchangeable K, soil solution K) to satisfy plant demand.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from depletion of NH4-OAc-K and NaBPh4-K pools.

cycling_processes.description: Vertical distribution of K in the soil profile, where K can accumulate in topsoil due to fertilizer application, root uptake from deeper layers and residue deposition in topsoil.
controlling_factors: Root uptake from deeper soil layers and residue deposition in topsoil
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Observed through vertical distribution patterns of NH4-OAc-K and NaBPh4-K.

plant_soil_interactions.description: Plants acquire K from all soil layers explored by roots, with varying uptake patterns depending on crop species and K distribution.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Not specified beyond general crop growth.
influencing_factors: Vertical distribution of plant available K

plant_soil_interactions.description: Plants remobilize K from subsoil towards shallow layers, contributing to K availability in topsoil.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Exacerbated under minimum or no-tillage management where stover releases soluble K.
influencing_factors: Absence of fine-textured horizons (accentuated in Balducchi and La Blanca)

chemical_processes.characterization: The ability of soil to resist changes in K concentration, influenced by clay content and mineralogy.
environmental_controls: Silt content (contributes to cation exchange capacity in Pampean soils)
chemical_processes.implications: Higher buffer capacity can mask effects of continuous K removal.

chemical_processes.characterization: K is distributed in four pools: soil solution K, exchangeable K (NH4-OAc-K), slowly exchangeable K (NaBPh4-K), and K-bearing primary minerals.
chemical_processes.implications: Fertilizer recommendations are mostly based on readily available fractions (soil solution K and NH4-OAc-K).

climate_conditions.seasonality: Temperate climate, early spring sampling mentioned.

soil_properties.classification: Mollisols (predominant soil order in the Pampas Region). Specific sites: Balducchi (Typic Hapludolls), San Alfredo (Typic Argiudolls), La Blanca (Typic Hapludolls), La Hansa (Aquic Argiudolls).
soil_properties.texture: Varies by site and depth. Clay and silt content are identified as controlling factors for K depletion.
soil_properties.mineralogy: Predominantly illite clay mineralogy of the parental material (loess). Silt fraction also contributes to cation exchange capacity with K-rich clay minerals.

landscape_context.topography: Not explicitly detailed, but 'on-farm trials' implies typical agricultural landscapes.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Sites differed in agricultural history at the beginning of the experiment (e.g., Balducchi +60 years, San Alfredo 8 years, La Blanca +6 years, La Hansa +20 years).

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K dynamics were related to grain yield, cumulative K removal (K budget), and other soil properties (clay, silt content, pristine K levels).
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: Integrated with crop K requirements, K removal by harvested product (maize, wheat, soybean), root K uptake patterns, and root activity at different depths.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: Aims to inform K management guidelines for high native K soils, emphasizing the need to consider both topsoil and subsoil nutrient status and variables related to soil K buffer capacity for more precise fertilizer needs.
research_integration.comparative_context: Results are compared with previous surveys in the Pampean Region, and K recommendation systems in the US Corn Belt (Iowa) and India.
research_integration.literature_positioning: Contributes to understanding K depletion in high native K soils, particularly the role of subsoil K, which is often overlooked in standard topsoil analyses.

measurement_constraints: No historical yield data was available to further explore hypotheses related to the effect of cropping history.
No grain-K measurements were made for the 2003–2009 period; average values from 2000–2002 were assumed to be constant for K removal calculations.
temporal_limitations: The 9-year study period, while long-term, may not fully capture very long-term K dynamics or recovery patterns.
spatial_limitations: While four sites were studied, the findings are specific to Pampean Mollisols and may not be directly transferable to other soil types or regions without further research.
methodological_constraints: Assumed negligible K losses from leaching and/or runoff.

The topsoil NH4-OAc-K test was found not highly sensitive to identify short-medium term K depletion trends in these high native K soils, indicating a limitation of this common diagnostic method in such contexts.
interpretation_caveats: The observed variability in soil K depletion is influenced by multiple factors (cropping history, soil texture, mineralogy, subsoil K supply) beyond just the K budget.
The study highlights the need for more comprehensive studies on soil-K depletion trends in response to different crop management practices for the Pampean Mollisols.
